column2: pronounced [pâːntʃeʋo]; German: Pantschowa; Hungarian: Pancsova; Romanian: Panciova; Slovak: Pánčevo) is a city and the administrative center of the South Banat District in the autonomous province of Vojvodina
column3: Serbia.

column1: Pančevo is the fourth largest city in Vojvodina by population. According to the 2011 census
column3: 203 inhabitants live in the urban area
column4: while the city administrative area of Pančevo has 123

column2: the town is known as Pančevo (Панчево)
column3: in Hungarian as Pancsova
column5: in Romanian as Panciova and in German as Pantschowa. The place name is probably derived from an old Slavonic term and meant location of marsh.

column1: Pančevo is located on flat plains at 44°52′14″N 20°38′25″E
column2: approximately 17 km NE of Pančevo bridge to Belgrade and 43 km NW of Smederevo. The altitude above sea level is 77 meters. The southern city quarters are located on the bank of the Danube
column3: the western quarters to the bank of Tamiš. The Danube river islands Forkontumac and Čakljanac are southernmost part of urban area.

column1: Pančevo has a humid subtropical climate (Köppen climate classification: Cfa).
In the late 19th and early 20th century many archaeological artifacts of the Stone Age period were found
column2: remains of settlements and places of burial from the times of Bronze Age (Urnfield culture) and Ancient Rome on the urban area. Most of the objects are exhibited at the National Museum of the town.

the Arabic Muslim geographer Muhammad al-Idrisi described the settlement as an important mercantile place and that is the first historical mentioning of the town. There is no deed or other evidence of founding the city. Today's urban area was administered by the Bulgarian Empire until the begin of the 11th century
column3: then by the Kingdom of Hungary until the 16th century
column4: when it became part of the Ottoman Empire in 1521. During the Ottoman rule
column5: the city was part of the Temeşvar Eyalet and mostly populated by ethnic Serbs. In 1660
column6: Evliya Çelebi described the town as a quadrangular fortification being diameter of one hundred Turkish feet. During the Austro-Turkish War
column7: the fortification was conquered by Claude Florimond de Mercy and his troops in 1716. There is an impression of the old city and its fortification recorded on maps from 1717 and 1720 which are located at National Széchényi Library and Institute of Military History in Budapest.After the Treaty of Požarevac
column8: the city belonged to Habsburg's Banat. The town was a Garrison place of temporarily stationed Regiments of Imperial Army. In December 1764
column9: a military commission of Viennese Hofkriegsrat registered 564 Rascian people who lived in 203 more or less habitable houses. Since this time Habsburg's administration encouraged massive immigration of German settlers to develop the new district of Military Frontier
column11: Francis II signed the charter of borough rights of Pančevo. Approximately
column12: in the middle of the 19th century
column13: the fortification has been slighted for urban expanding. In 1873
column14: the military frontier was abolished and Pančevo included into Torontál county of Austria-Hungary. In 1902
column15: cadastral maps of the town were recorded which are located at the National Archives of Hungary.

column2: the city was part of provisional Torontalsko-tamiške županja (Treaty of Trianon)
column3: in 1922 of Belgrade Oblast and since 1929 of the Danube Banovina in the Kingdom of Yugoslavia. In April 1941
column4: Pančevo was occupied during the invasion of Yugoslavia by Germany. Soldiers of Division Grossdeutschland committed a war crime in the city when 36 Serbian civilians were executed by hanging and shooting as a reprisal for the deaths of 9 Danube Swabian members of the paramilitary formation Deutsche Mannschaft
column5: a member of SS Division Das Reich and a wounded member of that division
column6: shot by unknown soldiers of Royal Yugoslav Army after Yugoslav surrender. Propaganda photos and film of the executions were used decades after the event to help chronicle the Wehrmacht's complicity in German atrocities during the war.During World War II in Yugoslavia
column7: Pančevo was part of Autonomous Banat within German-occupied Serbia. Political prisoners of National Socialism and Communism has been killed on location named Stratište. Selected Danube Swabian men were recruited and conscripted in the Waffen-SS
column8: majority of them either in SS-Division Das Reich
column9: in German Police or SS Freiwilligen Gebirgsjäger Division Prinz Eugen. More than 99 percent of local German women and youth were organized in formations Deutsche Frauenschaft and Deutsche Jugend and dedicated to National Socialism. In 1944
column10: after defeat of German Wehrmacht and Waffen-SS during Belgrade Offensive by Allied Armies
column11: one part of the German people left the city
column12: together with defeated German army. The other part of German people remained in the country. These people were sent into local imprisonments which existed until 1948. After dissolution
column13: many people of German population left Yugoslavia because of economic reasons. Since 1945
column14: the city belonged to the Srez Pančevo of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia and the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. The city was the administrative center of the region from all these centuries to the present.

column1: The administration of the municipality of Pančevo is structured in 9 local communities (Mesna zajednica
column2: singular; abbreviation MZ) of seven villages
column3: two towns and the city of Pančevo
column4: structured in eight local communities of eight city districts with several quarters.

column1: The administrative area differs to the historical administrative area. From 1946 to 1959
column2: the historical municipality (Srez) was structured in 23 communities
column3: including today's communities and the villages and cities of Baranda
column14: Uzdin and Vojlovica. The city district Vojlovica was added to the town in 1978.

The oldest and most traditional cultural institution of the city is the Serbian Church Choral Society
column2: founded in 1838 and the oldest still existing Choral Society of today's Serbia. Since its inception
column3: probably the most famous of all honorable choirmasters is Davorin Jenko
column4: who conducted the choir from 1863 to 1865. In the present
column5: the choir is conducted for the fourth time in a continuous sequence by a woman. The most important Cultural Center of the city (Kulturni Centar Pančeva) is located in the former theater building of the city
column6: founded in 1947 and named National Theater which realized play productions in cooperation with National Theater Novi Sad. In 1956
column7: the political authorities of the town decided the creation of a cultural center which is representing variety of all Arts. The center has a gallery of Modern art
column8: and it promotes continuous festivals like Biennial of Art (Bijenale umetnosti)
column9: the music festival Ethno.com and the Pančevački Jazz Festival with artists from all over the world. In addition
column10: some theater productions are shown annually in cooperation with National Theater Belgrade and other famous institutions. In 2012
column11: the center published all popular stories of Zigomar Comics in a collected edition. Since 1977
column12: the House of Youth (Dom omladine) is venue of the event Rukopisi (Manuscripts) where young writers are presented each year. The facility also promotes many other events like FreeDOM Art Festival. There is also the continuous Film festival PAFF worth mentioning which has a good reputation beyond the region. In the past
column13: the city has been filming location for many national and international movie productions
column14: including well known movies such as La Tour
column21: each year in June the Pančevački Carnival become the most important event of its kind in Serbia. The highlight of the event is the parade which goes through the center with more than over 3
column23: 000 visitors annually. The city is a member of the Federation of European Carnival Cities.

column1: The National Museum was founded in 1923 and it is located in former neoclassical city hall since several decades. The institution has a valuable permanent exhibition and it is one of the most important museums of Vojvodina. The Vajfert Brewery is located in the town's center and it is the oldest one of today's Serbia
column2: founded in 1722 by Abraham Kepiš from Bratislava. The brewery was run by the Vajfert family for several generations and its most famous represent was Đorđe Vajfert. After closing in 2008 and a conflagration in 2010
column3: the building complex was a ruin in recent years. In 2015
column4: the city began to realize a concept for revitalizing the industrial heritage and in the following year
column5: the Đorđe Vajfert Brewery Museum was opened in the presence of the Austrian and German ambassadors. In the same year
column6: a new summer festival called Vajfert Days was held for the first time. The intention of the organizer is to promote the tourist
column8: artistic and economic potential of the city. And last but not least
column9: there is an Archive of the City
column10: founded in 1947 and it is located in former barracks of Austrian-Hungarian Army. The archive collects and preserves materials of town's history from all centuries.

column1: Pančevo's Vojlovica monastery is one of the oldest monasteries of Vojvodina
column2: the oldest sacral building complex of the city and declared Cultural Monument of Exceptional Importance. In 1542
column3: the monastery was first mentioned by hegumen Jeronomah Parfenije in a Serbian almanac of Božidar Vuković. The church of the monastery is dedicated to Archangels Michael and Gabriel and was transformed into neoclassical stile towards the end of 18th century. From 1942 to 1944
column4: some Orthodox dignitaries such as Gavrilo V were temporarily imprisoned in the monastery and the entire building complex was observed by members of Deutsche Mannschaft including obligation to regularly report for Banater Staatswache. The oldest church in town is the Roman Catholic Church Saint Charles Borromeo
column6: the building was extended with a steeple which was equipped with a turret clock in 1868 to mark its centenary. Its column in the square in front of the building with statue of Abraham and Isaac was built in 1722. The building was previously used as a provisional church of a Minorite monastery. The religious order provided the military chaplains for the garrison of the Imperial Army. The Serbian Orthodox Church Assumption of Holy Virgin was built from 1807 to 1811. The iconostasis of the church was designed by the painter Konstantin Danil from 1828 to 1833. The urban Institute for Protection of Cultural Monuments supports the maintenance and restoration of Pančevo's Cultural Heritage.

column1: The weekly newspaper Pančevac is oldest one of still existing print media in Serbia
column3: weekly newspaper Libertatea is most widely used print media of Romanians in Serbia
column4: its first edition has been published in May 1945. The most used local mass media is RTV Pančevo. The TV station started broadcasting its programs in 1992.

column1: Pančevo is the economic center of South Banat District. There are many industrial companies in processing of oil
column3: aluminum
column16: thermal power stations and buildings of steel beams.

column1: Pančevo's economy is tied up with Belgrade economy
column2: as the distance between the cities is only 14 kilometers. The industrial site of NIS refinery is the largest one of all refineries in Serbia. In 1999
column3: the industrial site was strategically bombed by NATO bombing of Yugoslavia.

the Utva aircraft industry and HIP factory. The UNEP reported in studies about soil and groundwater contamination caused by NATO bombardment. The contamination is a long-term threat to natural environment and human health.There are two protected natural resources located in surroundings of the city

column1: The most important road that runs through Pančevo is the European route E70 which forms a bypass around the city center
column2: connecting the city with Belgrade. The IB-14 highway to Smederevo via Kovin starts here
column3: and so does the IIA-130 highway to Ečka. As the most important regional mode of transport on road is made available a bus route network for public passenger traffic by Autotransport Pančevo since 1948.Having a relatively small population
column4: Pančevo has no less than four passenger railway stations: Pančevo Glavna stanica
column6: Pančevo Strelište and Pančevo Vojlovica. Apart from these
column7: Serbian Railways also serve some important industries
column8: such as NIS oil refinery and HIP Azotara. In April 1894
column9: the city was connected to the European railways net.The municipality lays on left bank downriver of Danube which is one of the Europe's main waterways. The new harbor was built in 1947
column10: Tamiš discharges into Danube just outside the town of Pančevo.
